recipe_title: The Best Buttermilk-Brined Southern Fried Chicken Recipe

can you tell me the history of this chicken recipe. it appears to have a lot of ingredients that could make a nice blend
Next

That's a great question! t was the Scottish who were the first Europeans to deep fry their chicken in fat (though without seasoning). Meanwhile, a number of West African peoples had traditions of seasoned fried chicken (through battering and cooking the chicken in palm oil). Scottish frying techniques and West African seasoning techniques were combined by enslaved Africans and African-Americans in the American South.

provenance.paragraph_text: The first dish known to have been deep fried was fritters, which were popular in the European Middle Ages. However, it was the Scottish who were the first Europeans to deep fry their chicken in fat (though without seasoning). Meanwhile, a number of West African peoples had traditions of seasoned fried chicken (though battering and cooking the chicken in palm oil). Scottish frying techniques and West African seasoning techniques were combined by enslaved Africans and African-Americans in the American South.

Buttermilk has a tenderizing effect on food

provenance.page_title: The Best Southern Fried Chicken | The Food Lab
provenance.paragraph_text: Not only did the chicken come out just as moist as with water brine, it was actually significantly more tender as well, due to the tenderizing effects of buttermilk on food (soaking it for more than one night led to chicken that was so tender that it bordered on mush).

Brining is the process by which a lean meat (most often chicken, turkey, or pork) is submerged in a saltwater solution. As the meat sits, the saltwater will slowly dissolve key muscle proteins. As proteins dissolve, three things take place:

provenance.page_title: The Best Southern Fried Chicken | The Food Lab
provenance.paragraph_text: Brining is the process by which a lean meat (most often chicken, turkey, or pork) is submerged in a saltwater solution.

provenance.page_title: The Best Southern Fried Chicken | The Food Lab
provenance.paragraph_text: As the meat sits, the saltwater will slowly dissolve key muscle proteins—most notably myosin, a protein that acts as a sort of glue, holding muscle fibers together).

provenance.page_title: The Best Southern Fried Chicken | The Food Lab
provenance.paragraph_text: As the myosin dissolves, three things take place:

conversation.utterance: First, the ability of the meat to hold onto moisture increases.

provenance.page_title: The Best Southern Fried Chicken | The Food Lab
provenance.paragraph_text: First, the ability of the meat to hold onto moisture increases.

conversation.utterance: Second, brining alters the texture of the meat by allowing dissolved proteins to cross-link with each other.

provenance.page_title: The Best Southern Fried Chicken | The Food Lab
provenance.paragraph_text: Second, brining alters the texture of the meat by allowing dissolved proteins to cross-link with each other.

conversation.utterance: Third, as the brine slowly works its way into the meat, it seasons it beyond just the very surface.

provenance.page_title: The Best Southern Fried Chicken | The Food Lab
provenance.paragraph_text: Third, as the brine slowly works its way into the meat, it seasons it beyond just the very surface.

conversation.utterance: Hence,  an overnight brine will penetrate a few millimeters into the meat, giving you built-in seasoning before you ever get to the breading.

provenance.page_title: The Best Southern Fried Chicken | The Food Lab
provenance.paragraph_text: An overnight brine will penetrate a few millimeters into the meat, giving you built-in seasoning before you ever get to the breading.

With regards to the tenderizing properties of buttermilk, is it the milk that makes it to have such properties? what is buttermilk. butter and milk?
NEXT

No it's the buttermilk.  Buttermilk is a fermented dairy drink. Traditionally, it was the liquid left behind after churning butter out of cultured cream. However, most modern buttermilk is cultured.It can be used in marination, especially of chicken and pork, which the lactic acid helps to tenderize, retain moisture and allows added flavors to permeate the meat.

provenance.paragraph_text: Buttermilk is a fermented dairy drink. Traditionally, it was the liquid left behind after churning butter out of cultured cream. However, most modern buttermilk is cultured. It is common in warm climates (including the Balkans, South Asia, the Middle East and the Southern United States) where unrefrigerated fresh milk sours quickly.

Buttermilk can be drunk straight, and it can also be used in cooking. In making Soda bread, the acid in buttermilk reacts with the raising agent, sodium bicarbonate, to produce carbon dioxide which acts as the leavening agent. Buttermilk is also used in marination, especially of chicken and pork, which the lactic acid helps to tenderize, retain moisture and allows added flavors to permeate the meat.

why coat the chicken in flour mixture?
That's because you want to form a crust that was light and crisp.

provenance.page_title: The Best Southern Fried Chicken | The Food Lab
provenance.paragraph_text: Adding a couple teaspoons of baking powder to the mix helped bring a bit of air to the mix, forming a crust that was lighter and crisper, with increased surface area (and we all know that more surface area = more crispness, right?).

conversation.utterance: User moved to section "Step 4".
now this is an interesting step! why would be fry and then put it in the oven? what is the science and thought-process behind this technique
Also why heat the oil to a specific temperature. what happens if it's a hotter than specified or colder than specified?

You want to avoid the coating overcooking long before the chicken is cooked through to the center. For this reason, you need to fry the chicken until golden brown, then transfer it to a hot oven to finish cooking at a gentler pace. The result is chicken with a deep brown, craggy crust that's shatteringly crisp but not tough and that breaks away to the meat that bursts with intensely seasoned juices underneath.

provenance.page_title: The Best Southern Fried Chicken | The Food Lab
provenance.paragraph_text: The last problem—the coating overcooking long before the chicken is cooked through to the center—was simple to solve.

provenance.paragraph_text: Just fry the chicken until golden brown, then transfer it to a hot oven to finish cooking at a gentler pace.

any more interesting facts about the history of this recipe?
The Roman cookbook of "Apicius" (4th century) has a recipe for deep-fried chicken called "Pullum Frontonianum".

provenance.paragraph_text: The Roman cookbook of "Apicius" (4th century) has a recipe for deep-fried chicken called "Pullum Frontonianum".

conversation.utterance: Is there a special name for this technique?
The technique referred to in the late Roman cookbook of "Apicius" (c. 400), is simply named deep frying.

provenance.paragraph_text: Frying food in olive oil is attested in Classical Greece from about the 5th century BCE. The late Roman cookbook of "Apicius" (c. 400), appears to list the ancient Romans' first use of deep frying to prepare Pullum Frontonianum, a chicken dish. The practice of deep frying spread to other parts of Europe and Arabia in the following centuries. Deep-fried foods such as funnel cakes arrived in northern Europe by the 13th century, and deep-fried fish recipes have been found in cookbooks in Spain and Portugal at around the same time. Falafel arrived in the Middle East from population migrations from Egypt as soon as the 14th century.
